metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: HTML Accessibility
HTML Accessibility
Always write HTML code with accessibility in mind!
content.html: Always write HTML code with accessibility in mind!

content.text: Provide the user a good way to navigate and interact with your site. Make your HTML code as semantic as possible.
content.html: Provide the user a good way to navigate and interact with your site. Make your HTML code as semantic as possible.

content.text: Semantic HTML

Semantic HTML means using correct HTML elements for their correct purpose as much as possible. Semantic elements are elements with a meaning; if you need a button, use the <button> element (and not a <div> element).
content.html: Semantic HTML means using correct HTML elements for their correct purpose as much as possible. Semantic elements are elements with a meaning; if you need a button, use the <button> element (and not a <div> element).

content.code_html: <button>Report an Error</button>
<div>Report an Error</div>

content.text: Semantic HTML gives context to screen readers, which read the contents of a page out loud.
content.html: Semantic HTML gives context to screen readers, which read the contents of a page out loud.

content.text: With the button example in mind:
content.html: With the button example in mind:

content.text: A button is also accessible for people relying on keyboard-only navigation; it can be clickable with both mouse and keys, and it can be tabbed between (using the tab key on the keyboard).
content.html: A button is also accessible for people relying on keyboard-only navigation; it can be clickable with both mouse and keys, and it can be tabbed between (using the tab key on the keyboard).

content.text: Examples of non-semantic elements: <div> and <span> - Tells nothing about its content.
content.html: Examples of non-semantic elements: <div> and <span> - Tells nothing about its content.

content.text: Examples of semantic elements: <form> , <table> , and <article> - Clearly defines its content.
content.html: Examples of semantic elements: <form>, <table>, and <article> - Clearly defines its content.

content.text: Headings Are Important
Headings are defined with the <h1> to <h6> tags:
content.html: Headings are defined with the <h1> to <h6> tags:

content.code_html:
<h1>Heading 1</h1>
<h2>Heading 2</h2>
<h3>Heading 3</h3>
<h4>Heading 4</h4>
<h5>Heading 5</h5>
<h6>Heading 6</h6>

content.text: Search engines use the headings to index the structure and content of your web pages.
content.html: Search engines use the headings to index the structure and content of your web pages.

content.text: Users skim your pages by its headings. It is important to use headings to show the document structure and the relationships between different sections.
content.html: Users skim your pages by its headings. It is important to use headings to show the document structure and the relationships between different sections.

content.text: Screen readers also use headings as a navigational tool. The different types of heading specify the outline of the page. <h1> headings should be used for main headings, followed by <h2> headings, then the less important <h3> , and so on.
content.html: Screen readers also use headings as a navigational tool. The different types of heading specify the outline of the page. <h1> headings should be used for main headings, followed by <h2> headings, then the less important <h3>, and so on.

content.text: Note: Use HTML headings for headings only. Don't use headings to make text BIG or bold .
content.html: Note: Use HTML headings for headings only. Don't use headings to make text BIG or bold.

content.text: Alternative Text
The alt attribute provides an alternate text for an image, if the user for some reason cannot view it (because of slow connection, an error in the src attribute, or if the user uses a screen reader).
content.html: The alt attribute provides an alternate text for an image, if the user for some reason cannot view it (because of slow connection, an error in the src attribute, or if the user uses a screen reader).

content.text: The value of the alt attribute should describe the image:
content.html: The value of the alt attribute should describe the image:

syntaxHighlighting.text: src="img_chania.jpg" alt="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"
="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"

syntax_highlighting.text: src="img_chania.jpg" alt="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"
="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"

content.code_html: <img src="img_chania.jpg" alt="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania">

syntax_highlighting_data.text: src="img_chania.jpg" alt="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"
="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"

content.text: If a browser cannot find an image, it will display the value of the alt attribute:
content.html: If a browser cannot find an image, it will display the value of the alt attribute:

syntaxHighlighting.text: src="wrongname.gif" alt="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"
="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"

syntax_highlighting.text: src="wrongname.gif" alt="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"
="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"

content.code_html: <img src="wrongname.gif" alt="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania">

syntax_highlighting_data.text: src="wrongname.gif" alt="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"
="A narrow city street with flowers in Chania"

content.text: Declare the Language
You should always include the lang attribute inside the <html> tag, to declare the language of the Web page. This is meant to assist search engines and browsers.
content.html: You should always include the lang attribute inside the <html> tag, to declare the language of the Web page. This is meant to assist search engines and browsers.

content.text: The following example specifies English as the language:
content.html: The following example specifies English as the language:

content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<body>

...

</body>
</html>

content.text: Use Clear Language
Always use a clear language, that is easy to understand. Also try to avoid characters that cannot be read clearly by a screen reader. For example:
content.html: Always use a clear language, that is easy to understand. Also try to avoid characters that cannot be read clearly by a screen reader. For example:

content.text: Create Good Link Text
A link text should explain clearly what information the reader will get by clicking on that link.
content.html: A link text should explain clearly what information the reader will get by clicking on that link.

content.text: Examples of good and bad links:
content.html: Examples of good and bad links:

content.code_html:
Find out more about the HTML language

Read more about how to eat healthy

Buy tickets to Mars here

Click here

Read more..

Buy tickets to Mars here

content.text: Note: This page is an introduction in web accessibility. Visit our Accessibility Tutorial for more details.
content.html: Note: This page is an introduction in web accessibility. Visit our Accessibility Tutorial for more details.
